qas.question: What are bare-board tests looking for besides "opens"?
What's an absent connection that needs to be linked up on an unpopulated board called?
What conductive metal are the lands on a circuit board made out of?
What does a flying probe tester deliver to the contact points during testing?
What system tells the flying probe where to go and what to do?

plausible_answers.text: two points that should not be connected

qas.question: A long is a connection between what?
A closed is a missing connection between what?
Building the adapter is low cost and economical for?

context: Unpopulated boards are usually <b5_0>bare-board tested for <a0_0>"shorts"<a0_0/> and "opens"<b5_0/>. A short is a connection between <b6_0>two points that should not be connected<b6_0/>. <a1_0>An open<a1_0/> is a missing connection between <b7_0>points that should be connected<b7_0/>. For high-volume production a fixture or a rigid needle adapter is used to make contact with copper lands on the board. Building the adapter is a significant fixed cost and is only economical for <b8_0>high-volume or high-value production<b8_0/>. For small or medium volume production flying probe testers are used where test probes are moved over the board by an XY drive to make contact with the <a2_0>copper<a2_0/> lands. The <a4_0>CAM system<a4_0/> instructs the electrical tester to apply a <a3_0>voltage<a3_0/> to each contact point as required and to check that this voltage appears on the appropriate contact points and only on these.
